parts.title: Summary of the Foreword and Preface
parts.body: The Engineering Leader by Cate Huston is for engineering leaders and individual contributors. It emphasizes the importance of first focusing on self-care and career growth before leading others. Cate shares tools and strategies to succeed in managing teams and yourself, aiming to help leaders create high-functioning and fulfilling work environments. The book is divided into two parts - personal development and team scaling, containing action plans and reflection prompts for readers.

parts.title: Navigating Career Decisions: Flexibility and Reflection
parts.body: The writer reflects on career choices, discussing how decisions can feel daunting, such as taking on a big project or new job, and the fear of failure. They discuss the perils of indecision, which can lead to stagnation. Societal pressures often impose certain expectations, but the writer advises against following these blindly. Instead, they advocate for a framework to help individuals make deliberate career decisions, focusing on opportunity planning rather than strictly laid-out plans, ensuring work caters more to life's broader goals rather than just job titles. A story from Ellen Chisa illustrates choosing unexpected opportunities over traditional paths, emphasizing career flexibility. The narrative encourages reflecting on what career options you'd like to keep open. Another anecdote highlights how sudden changes (like the COVID-19 pandemic) can disrupt career plans, necessitating adaptation and reassessment of both career and personal aspirations. Through these perspectives, the key takeaway is maintaining a balance between advancing career goals while staying open to shifting circumstances.

parts.title: The Importance of Flexibility and Realizing Your Worth
parts.body: The experience taught me about the importance of flexibility and the ability to pivot when situations change. While plans are crucial, being open to rewriting them when faced with life's unpredictability is equally important. In one of my roles, I joined a company that rejected traditional wisdom but offered me a great opportunity without relocation. However, after a difficult 18 months, even though we became a high-performing team, there was no pay raise or promotion as they didn’t really exist in the organization. Instead, I took on another team because I valued being a team player and it provided more optionality for my career. Unfortunately, my role evolved into something resembling a VPE job without the title or compensation. I was responsible for scaling hiring and managing recruiters, as well as supporting leads in a structurally challenged system, which left me with responsibility but no power or decision-making ability. The job's demands made me less employable because the job entailed ownership of processes but not outcomes. The organizational values weren't changing at a pace that suited me, leading me to realize that I was making myself less marketable while being underpaid. This realization prompted clarity that what I was trading with my employer wasn’t worth it in the long run, which eventually led me to leave as the value they were buying and renting was deteriorating my career prospects.

parts.title: Understanding and Evaluating Opportunities
parts.body: Opportunities can be given, planted, or picked. "Given opportunities" are straightforward offers you accept. "Planted opportunities" are those you create for yourself, like submitting proposals for public speaking. "Picked opportunities" are the results of your efforts, like your articles leading to a talk invitation. Evaluate opportunities by asking questions: what can you learn, or what impact will it have? Consider your relationship with the person offering the opportunity — this helps in assessing worthiness. Sometimes, an opportunity may seem more like additional work rather than a chance for growth, so you must critically evaluate.

parts.title: Work Friendships and Emotional Labor
parts.body: It's important for managers to support their direct reports, as well as manage up by showing support to their bosses. This can be emotionally draining, and sometimes it feels like no one looks out for them. A work BFF can be a source of support during tough days, offering help and access to informal networks without fear of judgment. Building a work BFF relationships takes time, just like any friendship. If you have one, let them know how much they mean to you—it’s likely they feel the same. Despite the benefits, friendships at work can also be seen as cliquey, which can exclude others. It’s important to welcome all team members into interactions and avoid monopolizing each other's time at work events. Be mindful of the balance between cultivating close friendships and fostering an inclusive work environment.

parts.title: Mentorship & Small Actions Impact on Careers
parts.body: Mentorship is about expanding capacity, not ignoring reality. DEI efforts often focus on grand changes but miss the impact of small actions. These actions can help under-indexed individuals even if we lack power. An example is a tweet from the author which helped Jazbo Beason, a self-taught iOS engineer who immigrated from Jamaica. Though his medical career didn’t work out, he taught himself to create iPhone apps. Seeing the tweet, he reached out. Mentorship transitioned into sponsorship, where the author provided mock interviews and connected him to opportunities at Glowforge, later leading him to Apple.

parts.title: Clarifying Deal and Objectives
parts.body: In Step 3, clarify the deal you've made with your employer by considering what they're renting (i.e., your skills and contributions), and what they're buying. Assess whether you're building market value or undermining it, and if the employer is taking more than they're compensating for. Determine the kind of deal you want and how it aligns with your long-term goals and immediate life needs. For Step 4, set proximate objectives by defining short-term goals that align with your career options. Create development plans for each goal and find someone to help discuss and refine these plans.

parts.title: Understanding and Managing Burnout
parts.body: To manage burnout, consider both work and personal life. Problems outside work can affect work, while deep relationships and hobbies can buffer against burnout. Work-life balance means doing more life, not less work. Understanding burnout causes at work (lack of control, reward, fairness, community, value conflict, and overload) helps pinpoint where issues lie in both work and life. Examine each cause, even if minor. Improvement might lie outside of work. Writing exercises or discussions with a coach can help identify burnout drivers. For change, knowledge of causes creates a plan—know what needs altering and why. Often, broad problems with energy management stem from indecision. Start by picking a small, actionable change. Give it time** before evaluating its effectiveness.

parts.title: Fear in Management: Overcoming Reluctance and Embracing Change
parts.body: When faced with tough team dynamics, individuals, especially managers, often resist confronting challenges, fearing various outcomes such as feeling overwhelmed, loss of status, or inadequate delegation. This is illogical and counterproductive. It’s crucial for managers to confront team challenges as part of their role, recruit support when needed, and systematically delegate tasks. Managers' reluctance stems from fear of losing control or not meeting standards but evolving team and role responsibilities is essential. Additionally, holding onto unnecessary tasks impairs productivity and strategic development.

parts.title: Leadership Styles and Communication Challenges
parts.body: This section discusses communication failure modes that can lead to problems in the workplace. Key issues include lack of depth, conflicting context, too much empathy, missing empathy, and assuming unearned trust. For instance, lacking depth can stall forward progress, while too much empathy can delay necessary changes. On the other hand, missing empathy can demoralize teams during organizational changes. Resolving these issues involves addressing scope, complexity, output, and agenda, each offering growth opportunities as you adapt your leadership strategies. The text also covers leadership styles, focused on six from Goleman: pacesetting, authoritative, affiliative, coaching, coercive, and democratic. Understanding and expanding your range of leadership styles is essential in adapting to different situations. For example, pacesetting is effective during high-pressure times demanding high standards, but can overwhelm teams. Authoritative leadership helps guide lost teams but requires confidence and expertise. Knowing which style to employ can maximize your impact and team alignment.

parts.title: Engineering Teams and Business Value
parts.body: Engineering Teams focus on three elements: people, projects, and process. They succeed when they deliver business value predictably and effectively. Process isn't the priority, but a tool that's evolved to meet needs. We previously focused on personal development, now we shift to team progress. Teams exist to deliver business value; hence engineers' high compensation. This value is tied to achieving business goals through effective team scaling, often challenged by "growing pains" or "strategic deficiencies". The book aims to guide managers in developing more effective teams. If you're not a manager, it provides insight into funnelling improvements into clear strategic insights to influence change.

parts.title: Scaling Teams Effectively
parts.body: Scaling Teams involves navigating the challenges of growth in companies that once prioritized rapid expansion over business fundamentals. In the past, adding people hastily without a well-thought hiring process led to issues in performance management, onboarding, and team diversity. Effective people management must include direct management and create an ecosystem that supports strong integration. Clear models and support networks can help manage short feedback loops and aid in hiring and onboarding. Attrition rates, manager development, and strategic alignment with organizational values are key to maintaining a scalable workforce, emphasizing that both people problems and process problems are necessary to address in scaling strategies. Setting up teams to grow involves understanding and adjusting the hiring process to improve diversity and effective integration. Metrics such as diversity percentage and process effectiveness are crucial to assess current practices. Establishing secure environments for onboarding and training is addressed alongside asserting time and process constraints during hiring. Diverse teams thrive in healthy environments, requiring constant reiteration and ecosystem support to accommodate evolving markets. Leaders must address these elements incrementally to drive sustainable and meaningful change that doesn’t just maintain but enhances team cohesion and functionality.

parts.title: Enhancing Diversity in Hiring & Structured Evaluation
parts.body: To improve the hiring process and embrace diversity, prioritize having recruiters focused on connecting with under-indexed candidates and listen to their feedback. Recruiter diversity contributes to better candidate experience and conversion rates. Building strong partnerships with recruiters, allowing them to give insights on favorited candidates, and spending extra time on candidate calls are essential strategies. Diversified job descriptions should focus on being an invitation rather than a filter, emphasizing growth opportunities and inclusive language. A properly structured evaluation process minimizes bias by clearly outlining competencies and mapping them to specific selection stages. Adopt methods like an evaluation matrix to identify gaps in current processes and address them. Evaluations should focus on specific actions rather than characteristics to assess competency effectively, ensuring that candidates are aware of what's being evaluated. Behavioral assessments such as response to feedback are key to identifying a candidate's potential for growth.

parts.title: Interview Strategies and Techniques
parts.body: Behavioral interviews aim to evaluate if a candidate will fit and succeed within a team. Interviewers assess how candidates make decisions, their interaction style, and what they're seeking in a job. Coding and technical interviews evaluate a candidate's technical competence and problem-solving methods. Selecting good technical interview questions involves exploring questions that can be decomposed into smaller problems without a specific "gotcha" mindset. Allows candidates to get a strong signal on understanding, trade-offs, and explorability within technical domains.

parts.title: Cultivating Effective 1:1s and Supporting Onboarding
parts.body: 1:1 management sessions are essential for relationship-building. Instead of sticking to predefined questions, focus on understanding employee needs and guiding them to meet those needs, facilitating their growth beyond mere managerial assistance. Effective 1:1s follow a pattern involving support, direction, practical help, and feedback. It's about providing context, enabling practical help, and facilitating development through continuous feedback and coaching. Emphasizing developmental feedback encourages action and empowerment, moving away from a mere evaluation focus. Rather than just noting issues, complaints can be informative and foster trust. Complaints highlight potential areas of improvement, peoples' values, and can help resolve conflicts. Proper onboarding ensures a sense of belonging and accomplishment for new hires, preventing nonboarding situations, which require considerable recovery efforts. Finally, shifting onboarding to a collective responsibility enhances both belonging and accomplishment as new hires integrate into teams effectively. Cultivating a culture of helping within the team facilitates broader organizational success.

parts.title: Navigating Employee Challenges and Supporting Growth
parts.body: When managing employees going through hard times, consent and support are key. Instead of assigning tasks, offer options and collaborate on a plan to support them, valued above control. Ensure issues of basic decency, like addressing disrespect, are HR's duty rather than the employee's. Flexibility in time off, like unlimited leave, also empowers support. Addressing performance concerns requires a balance between organizational goals and individual circumstances. Challenges include providing clarity on expectations, understanding impact on the team, and navigating HR policies. As a buffer against possible turnover or "unregretted attrition", a well-built leadership bench is crucial. Develop potential leaders early and strategically use resources, ensuring smooth transitions and effective organizational growth.

parts.title: Growing Potential
parts.body: Developing Potential involves finding ways to grow your team, even if you're not directly involved with them. Rewards and incentives should align with desired behaviors and be set by coaching managers to offer the right opportunities. When thinking about stretch assignments, focus on growth opportunities that match people's goals. Ensure these assignments are recognized and set up for success. Be careful not to overpromise, as failing to provide promised resources may lead to dissatisfaction. Team support and mentorship play crucial roles in achieving success, and encouraging a culture of feedback, consisting of code review, calibration, and compliments, can be effective in shaping team culture.

parts.title: Clarifying Roles & Responsibilities
parts.body: When hiring a new team manager, it's crucial to clearly define their roles and responsibilities, ensuring everyone understands what they will and won't be accountable for. This minimizes confusion and prevents overlaps with others, such as HR or product teams. For instance, if hiring is not their responsibility, make sure your new hire offers productive feedback instead of attempting to run the process. This clarity is especially vital in untraditional workplaces where roles might not align with past experiences. Effectively setting clear boundaries helps new leaders build credibility and smoothly integrate into their roles.

parts.title: Optimizing Hiring Process
parts.body: The team improved their hiring process by breaking down goals into achievable steps. By modeling their system, they could identify interdependencies and eliminate bottlenecks. They shifted from a system where a few did a lot to having many do a little, which made work more manageable and increased engagement. They highlighted the importance of calibration to ensure consistency. The strategy led to hiring results, with the team hitting new hiring goals consistently. Optimism was sustained even in difficult times. They leveraged automation and technology like Calendly and a chatbot to reduce dependencies, reducing delays and making the process more efficient. Also, the evaluation process became more objective by using consistent rubrics, which increased fairness and confidence in hiring decisions. They also focused on appreciating team efforts, setting a positive culture, showing that the work was valuable and recognized, and celebrating achievements with gestures like cards and swag.

parts.title: Strategic Alignment & Process Implementation
parts.body: Strategic Alignment & Building Tactics: The text delves into the significance of clear execution layers, emphasizing how well-defined strategies and tactics lead to efficient execution within organizations. It illustrates how maintaining harmony among mission, strategy, tactics, and execution helps teams avoid dysfunction. A lack of clear communication can cause confusion, undermining efforts at various hierarchical levels. The text uses case studies to demonstrate how introducing organized processes like prioritization exercises, clear deadlines, and on-call support structures can help teams manage workload effectively and ensure accountability. Adjusting Process & Enabling Teams: The discussion highlights the importance of flexibility in processes, using "experiments" and small iterative changes to foster a culture of continuous improvement. It suggests aligning processes with team APIs, ensuring trust and communication flow smoothly across teams. The text emphasizes the role of leadership in creating clarity, avoiding micromanagement, and establishing trust within teams. Problems arise when process changes aren't communicated or embraced, often due to a mismatch in perceived size or necessity of these changes. Strategies for understanding and mitigating resistance to process changes are advised, ensuring each change aligns with desired cultural norms and enhances team functionality.

parts.title: Execution and Strategic Role of Leaders
parts.body: Execution is crucial but often undervalued because it only results in adequacy. Minor adjustments early on can lead to better outcomes and prevent execution from becoming a problem later on. Teams can keep execution smooth by maintaining clear communication and project management discipline. Understanding value and prioritizing strategy over mere execution are crucial for career advancement. Leaders are often trapped in proving execution abilities without recognition of their strategic skills.

parts.title: Key Team Communication Elements
parts.body: Meta chat is about discussions on improving how we work, empowering teams to enhance effectiveness. It's investment in improvement that's crucial. Constructive feedback is communicating what doesn't work and suggesting improvements, fostering direct communication without intermediaries, essential for trust in teams. Healthy conflict is constructive disagreement within a team, essential for psychological safety. It ensures diverse opinions are shared, leading to better conclusions. Together, these elements build a high-functioning team rather than one that just "pushes code" to a repo.

parts.title: Cate Huston's Professional Profile & Contributions
parts.body: Cate Huston is a renowned technology expert with a global career focusing on scaling teams and leading engineering organizations. Currently, she's an Engineering Director at DuckDuckGo, with past experience at Automattic. She’s also trained in Co-Active coaching, being a Limited Partner at a VC fund, and advisor at Glowforge. Cate earned a BSc in computer science from the University of Edinburgh and started her career at Google. She’s a regular writer for Quartz and has contributed to collections like 97 Things Every Engineering Manager Should Know. Besides her engineering roles, Cate’s expertise extends to speaking internationally and appearing as a tech industry expert on shows like The Today Show (US) and Channel 4 News (UK). Her writing spans multiple well-known publications such as Lifehacker and The Daily Beast. Cate's work is referenced in books like The Manager’s Path and Brotopia, highlighting her as a significant voice in tech leadership and development.
